t: Job 13
“Behold,*pn my eye has seen all this,*i My*ld ear has heard and understood it.
What*ld you know, I also know; I*ld am*i not inferior to you.
But*ld I would speak to the Almighty, And*ld I desire to reason with God.
But*ld you forgers of lies, You*ld are*i all worthless physicians.
Oh,*ld that you would be silent, And*ld it would be your wisdom!
Now*ld hear my reasoning, And*ld heed the pleadings of my lips.
Will*ld you speak wickedly for God, And*ld talk deceitfully for Him?
Will*ld you show partiality for Him? Will*ld you contend for God?
Will*ld it be well when He searches you out? Or*ld can you mock Him as one mocks a man?
He*ld will surely rebuke you If*ld you secretly show partiality.
Will*ld not His excellence make you afraid, And*ld the dread of Him fall upon you?
Your*ld platitudes are*i proverbs of ashes, Your*ld defenses are defenses of clay.
“Hold*ln your peace with me, and let me speak, Then*ld let come on me what may!*i
Why*ld do I take my flesh in my teeth, And*ld put my life in my hands?
Though*ld He slay me, yet will I trust Him. Even*ld so, I will defend my own ways before Him.
He*ld also shall*i be my salvation, For*ld a hypocrite could not come before Him.
Listen*ld carefully to my speech, And*ld to my declaration with your ears.
See*ld now, I have prepared my*i case, I*ld know that I shall be vindicated.
Who*ld is*i he who*i will contend with me? If*ld now I hold my tongue, I perish.
Job’s Despondent Prayer
“Only*pn two things*i do not do to me, Then*ld I will not hide myself from You:
Withdraw*ld Your hand far from me, And*ld let not the dread of You make me afraid.
Then*ld call, and I will answer; Or*ld let me speak, then You respond to me.
How*ld many are*i my iniquities and sins? Make*ld me know my transgression and my sin.
Why*ld do You hide Your face, And*ld regard me as Your enemy?
Will*ld You frighten a leaf driven to and fro? And*ld will You pursue dry stubble?
For*ld You write bitter things against me, And*ld make me inherit the iniquities of my youth.
You*ld put my feet in the stocks, And*ld watch closely all my paths. You*ld set a limit for the soles of my feet.
“Man*iln decays like a rotten thing, Like*ld a garment that is moth-eaten.
